title: 112_s1375
content: The Act may be cited as the "Ending Excessive Corporate Deductions for Stock Options Act" and it aims to ensure consistent treatment of stock options by corporations. The "Ending Excessive Corporate Deductions for Stock Options Act" aims to ensure consistent treatment of stock options by corporations. It includes amendments to the Internal Revenue Code regarding the deduction of employer stock options. The "Ending Excessive Corporate Deductions for Stock Options Act" includes new subsection (q) regarding the treatment of compensation paid with stock options. It limits the deduction to the amount treated as compensation cost for income purposes and provides special rules for controlled groups. The "Ending Excessive Corporate Deductions for Stock Options Act" limits the deduction for compensation paid with stock options to the amount treated as compensation cost for income purposes. Special rules are provided for controlled groups. The "Ending Excessive Corporate Deductions for Stock Options Act" limits stock option deductions for compensation to income purposes. Amendments apply to options exercised after enactment, with exceptions for options granted before June 15, 2005. Public and non-public entities have specific reporting requirements. The "Ending Excessive Corporate Deductions for Stock Options Act" limits stock option deductions for compensation to income purposes. Amendments apply to options exercised after enactment, with exceptions for options granted before June 15, 2005. For non-public entities required to file public reports of financial condition, specific reporting requirements apply, including changes to vesting dates of stock options. No deduction allowed under certain sections of the Code if the vesting date is changed to avoid the amendments. The amendment to section 162(m)(4) of the Internal Revenue Code includes stock option compensation as applicable employee remuneration, affecting options exercised or granted after the enactment of the Act.
